description: {"blocks":[{"key":"4bmik","text":"This protocol describes how to isolate and purify nuclei from solid tissue for use in single-cell library construction methods. The resulting nuclei are suitable for a variety of single-cell assays such as droplet-based methods like 10x Genomics Chromium and hybridization-based methods like SHARE-seq. Through sequencing we have verified that the resulting nuclei created through this protocol show a low percentage of mitochondrial RNA. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6ve4a","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9lujm","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ddcu","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d8os6","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
disclaimer: {"blocks":[{"key":"duru8","text":"As always, when starting to plan a protocol which implicates usage of animal or human tissues, please ensure that you are working within an IACUC (animal work) or IRB (human work) approved protocol.  We highly recommend engaging with your institutional IACUC or IRB as part of the planning stages for experimentation.  Post-mortem tissue is a gift, it is our collective responsibility as scientists to ensure we use these tissues safely and ethically.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
ethics_statement: {"blocks":[{"key":"8chqs","text":"As always, when starting to plan a protocol which implicates usage of animal or human tissues, please ensure that you are working within an IACUC (animal work) or IRB (human work) approved protocol.  We highly recommend engaging with your institutional IACUC or IRB as part of the planning stages for experimentation. Mouse brain tissue used to prototype this protocol was purchased from TransNetyx (https://tissue.transnetyx.com/).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":400,"length":30}],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"5585546D661411EF8B450A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://tissue.transnetyx.com"}}}}
guidelines: {"blocks":[{"key":"7p3dj","text":"Use this protocol in accordance to your institution's human subject data policies if using any type of human tissue.  As always, when starting to plan a protocol which implicates usage of animal or human tissues, please ensure that you are working within an IACUC (animal work) or IRB (human work) approved protocol.  We highly recommend engaging with your institutional IACUC or IRB as part of the planning stages for experimentation.  Post-mortem tissue is a gift, it is our collective responsibility as scientists to ensure we use these tissues safely and ethically.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

status.info: We use this protocol and it's working

steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"dj513","text":"The buffers that are noted with a '*' such as HDT-2RI, HB, and NSB are calculated for 2.5 reactions and should be adjusted for more reactions accordingly. The buffers that are able to be stored can be considered as stock buffers and are good for several iterations of the protocol. Make more PBS wash buffer as you see fit for the number of washes you would like to do after filtering (the recommendation is at least two).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":46,"length":7},{"style":"bold","offset":55,"length":2},{"style":"bold","offset":63,"length":3}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"b6i7d","text":"The quantities below are calculated for 2.5 reactions - adjust the volumes to accommodate the number of gradients that you desire to make. It is suggested to plan to use 1 gradient per 1 million nuclei of a debris-dense sample but samples with less debris could be loaded with up to 10 million nuclei (such as mouse brain and pancreas). The iodixanol gradient purification should be done the same day as the nuclear isolation part of the protocol if the nuclei are intended to be used in SHARE-seq or similar methods.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2kt28","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f9jud","text":"Buffers {"blocks":[{"key":"29ajk","text":"This part of the protocol is designed to isolate nuclei from tissue and larger cellular debris. It is possible to use the crude nuclei pellet that comes from this section and proceed to the fixation step if debris is not a concern for your project. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"adso1","text":"Before nuclear isolation either section or pulverize the tissue sample:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"45r3s","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9iqq9","text":"     a. To section the sample, use a cryostat to section the tissue into 30-40 sections that are 100 μm    ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5dk8i","text":"          thick. To do this let the cryostat cool down, set section thickness to 100 μm, and attach the ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2qu54","text":"          back of your tissue sample to a target using Optimal Cutting Temperature (OCT). Once the ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7sjb1","text":"          OCT hardens, place your target on the target holder platform and insert your blade. Proceed ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bak01","text":"          by positioning the cryostat and begin sectioning. Place sections into either a 1.5 mL or 2 mL ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"69tv4","text":"          tube.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"76b01","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bde5o","text":"     b. To pulverize the tissue use a BioPulverizer. Clean your BioPulverizer with a disinfectant followed ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4h9mq","text":"          by RNaseZap to ensure best quality and place the BioPulverizer into an ice bucket. Fill the ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"efsqu","text":"          space around the BioPulverizer with about 3-4cm of liquid nitrogen and once cold place your ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"31us3","text":"          tissue sample inside the bottom component of your BioPulverizer. Re-combine the other ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2sp62","text":"          components of the BioPulverizer and smash the top of the BioPulverizer using the   ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"di2t","text":"          accompanying about 5-10 times. Aliquot the resulting powdered tissue into either 1.5 mL or 2 ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fvo52","text":"          mL tubes.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"fnjeo","text":"The purpose of this part of this protocol is to isolate the nuclei from the tissue and other cellular debris. It is possible to proceed to fixation and skip the nuclear purification portion of this protocol if debris is not a concern for your project.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"4cbq1","text":"Weigh your samples and record the weights for your own records in mg. Proceed to freeze the sample at -80 degrees C (no flash freezing) until ready to use. Use dry ice to transport your tissue. Note: It may be helpful to place any labels onto the corresponding tube prior to freezing. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":194,"length":91}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"frf6s","text":"Begin by cooling a 7 mL dounce on wet ice and resuspend your sectioned or pulverized tissue sample with 2 mL of NIM2 buffer. Using a wide-bore tip and a 1 mL pipette, transfer the entire sample into the dounce on ice. Triturate the sample with the same wide-bore tip 10x or until the sample is easy to pipette.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":112,"length":4}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"25osl","text":"Dounce the sample using the loose pestle (or A) for 20-30 full motions. Note: Cleaning the pestles with 70% ethanol and RNaseZap and placing the pestles momentarily in the freezer before douncing helps prevent potential early degradation of your sample.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":72,"length":181}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"42nqc","text":"Use an additional 2 mL of NIM2 to wash down any sample stuck to your pestle into the dounce (total volume = 4 mL). Set your loose pestle aside and let your sample sit on ice for 3-5 minutes.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":26,"length":4}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"f89nh","text":"Dounce the sample using the tight pestle (or B) for 20-30 full motions.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"ad58b","text":"Repeat step 5 with the tight pestle for a new resulting total of 6 mL of sample.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"fdqlp","text":"Transfer the entire sample from the dounce into a 50 mL conical tube and spin the sample 50xg (should be fine at any speed between 40-100xg) at 4ºC for 2 minutes.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"69ff4","text":"While waiting to pellet the larger material in your sample, on a new 50 mL conical tube on set up a 10 μm filter followed by a 40 μm filter on top. Once your sample is done spinning, transfer the complete supernatant while avoiding the pellet through the top 40 μm filter. Note: Some tissues are harder to get through the filters than others. In this case pipetting the sample at the base of the filter can help the sample pass through. Additionally, carefully disconnecting and then reconnecting the two filters from each other can release tension and also help the sample pass through.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":273,"length":314}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"d8788","text":"Once the entirety of the supernatant passes through the 40 μm filter, remove the 40 μm filter and discard it. Wash the 10 μm filter with 6 mL of PBS Wash Buffer. Pipetting periodically like in step 2.9 can help clear clogs if your sample is not passing through.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":145,"length":15}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"9ttms","text":"Spin the conical tube with your sample in it at 550xg for 5 minutes at 4ºC to pellet your nuclei.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"8isrn","text":"Carefully remove the supernatant and add 6 mL of PBS wash buffer to the conical tube without disturbing the nuclei pellet. Note: Set aside your supernatant in a separate conical tube as a back-up (in the case you lose your nuclei you can restart the wash/pelleting steps of this protocol.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":49,"length":15},{"style":"italic","offset":123,"length":165}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
{"blocks":[{"key":"6pff","text":"Spin again at 550xg for 5 minutes at 4ºC.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"7p70t","text":"Without disturbing the pellet, remove the supernatant to isolate a crude nuclei pellet.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"choqk","text":"Resuspend the pellet in 435 μL of freshly made NSB. Transfer the suspended nuclei into a new 2 mL tube that has been BSA coated. Note: To BSA coat a tube add 200 μl of 7.5% BSA to a tube, vortex it, and remove the remainder of the BSA with a pipette.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":47,"length":3},{"style":"italic","offset":128,"length":122}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"49kn1","text":"Count your nuclei using a hemocytometer and a microscope at 4-10x:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"e5o3s","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3rc33","text":"     a. If using trypan mix 10 μL of sample with 10 μL of trypan blue 0.4% solution. To calculate an ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7b4o1","text":"         estimate for the amount of nuclei in your sample, count an entire larger square grid (e.g. 5x5 or ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1l3n1","text":"         4x4) or multiply a subsection accordingly. Multiply your count by 20,000 and then multiply by ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cgmsc","text":"         the amount of your sample in mL (i.e. if you have 400 μL of sample, multiply by 0.4).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4mnqb","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dl6e4","text":"      b. If using propidium iodide (PI) mix 25 μL of sample with 1 μL of PI. To calculate an estimate of ","type":"unstyled","depth":1,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8gnp8","text":"          the amount of nuclei in your sample use the same calculation as above but multiply by 10,000 ","type":"unstyled","depth":1,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4ljoo","text":"          instead of 20,000 to account for the amount of sample used for this count. Note: It is highly ","type":"unstyled","depth":1,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":85,"length":19}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7a5m7","text":"          recommended to count with both Trypan and PI but it is highly recommended to use PI to ","type":"unstyled","depth":1,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":97}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c0cvh","text":"          count samples that you expect to be particularly debris-dense.","type":"unstyled","depth":1,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":72}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"denuo","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":1,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5e5fd","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":1,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"edaue","text":"The previous section for nuclear isolation should have left you with 400 μL of nuclei. You can proceed with the entirety of your sample or split you sample to multiple tubes. Using the counts you recorded you should aim to use about 1 million nuclei per gradient however it is possible to over for tissue types with less debris without overloading the gradient. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"rs9u","text":"Each iodixanol gradient should be done in a 2 mL BSA-coated tube. Split the sample into the desired amount of gradients and bring up the total volume of the sample to 400 μL with any leftover NSB. Note: It is recommended that debris-dense/most samples be processed at 1 million nuclei per gradient, however cleaner samples can be potentially loaded with more (such as mouse brain or human pancreas). ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":197,"length":203}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"368gu","text":"Mix 400 μL (1 volume) of 50% iodixanol to each gradient to obtain a final concentration of 25% iodixanol. Mix well.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":25,"length":13}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"fc05d","text":"Aspirate 600 μL of 30% iodixanol with a 1 mL pipette and use a kimwipe to wipe off any iodixanol from the outside of the pipette tip. Bring the tip all the way to the bottom of the tube and slowly add the 30% iodixanol layer being careful not to mix with the layer above.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":19,"length":13}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"bathf","text":"Aspirate 600 μL of 40% iodixanol with a 1 mL pipette and use a kimwipe to wipe off any iodixanol from the outside of the pipette tip. Bring the tip all the way to the bottom of the tube and slowly add the 40% iodixanol layer being careful not to mix with the top two layers. Note: With this layer slowly bring the top upwards when dispensing the layer to avoid overflowing the gradient.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":19,"length":13},{"style":"italic","offset":274,"length":112}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"1bqab","text":"Using a swinging-bucket centrifuge, spin your gradients at 3000xg for 20 min at 4ºC with the soft brake feature set “on.” Note: If the centrifuge does not have a soft brake feature make sure acceleration/deceleration is set to 0 since this is a key parameter to ensure you do not disrupt your gradients. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":122,"length":182}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"eumel","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"b8i93","text":"(!) It is critical to have the centrifuge on soft ramp/soft brake or acceleration at 0 in order to get a clear band of nuclei at the interphase of the 30% and 40% layers. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":171}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"ebq4","text":"While the gradient is on ice, use a 1 mL pipette to aspirate 500 μL from the top of the gradient (the purpose of this is to aspirate some of the topmost layer so the sample doesn’t overflow when aspirating your nuclei band). With the same pipette use a new tip and aspirate 400-600 μL of the nuclei band and transfer to a new 1.5 μL BSA-coated tube on ice. Note: The nuclei band may be hard to see or cloudy. Bring the gradient to a light source and tilt slightly towards you to see where the interphase between the two layers is and aspirate what you can from that area. It is recommended to only attempt to aspirate the nuclei band all at once for best yield.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"143le","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6qqg3","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"btbos","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"2B6F6C5A5B8B4A638DE56E62AB9C9334","height":"355px;","is_video":false,"legend":"{\"blocks\":[{\"key\":\"14an\",\"text\":\"Photo of nuclei band\",\"type\":\"unstyled\",\"depth\":0,\"inlineStyleRanges\":[],\"entityRanges\":[],\"data\":{}}],\"entityMap\":{}}","mime":null,"nestedSelector":null,"original_name":null,"placeholder":"https://lh7-us.googleusercontent.com/lx28WFjvGx8X9Ktqg9O88Mt92z5hxY3c1z8Y1HuI4Ar58_aqDg6l7PYlFqy6fzK5v32OMmxe9CSEBn-oGXvG4R8pR6Sa-WJbnWiTwxYhDY5_w-4zXb0XC7zK1_Br8tlPDZXMaM1dwAH3WPCh_qunuEtNnD8w2OHF=s2048","shadow":false,"source":"https://lh7-us.googleusercontent.com/lx28WFjvGx8X9Ktqg9O88Mt92z5hxY3c1z8Y1HuI4Ar58_aqDg6l7PYlFqy6fzK5v32OMmxe9CSEBn-oGXvG4R8pR6Sa-WJbnWiTwxYhDY5_w-4zXb0XC7zK1_Br8tlPDZXMaM1dwAH3WPCh_qunuEtNnD8w2OHF=s2048","width":"182px;"}}}}
{"blocks":[{"key":"e2258","text":"Count your nuclei (refer to step 2.16 of Nuclear Isolation).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"6pnaj","text":"Add ~1mL of HDT-2RI to dilute iodixanol and spin down at 750xg for 5 min at 4ºC to pellet nuclei. Remove supernatant and place the tube with your nuclei pellet on ice until you can proceed with fixation. For SHARE-seq go to fixation immediately.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":12,"length":7}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"222u0","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dh6tg","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"clebv","text":"Fixation of your nuclei is required for SHARE-seq if not done on the same day. If your project doesn't require fixation you can ignore this step and use your crude nuclei pellet.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"50k3v","text":"Add 1 mL of room-temperature HDT-2RI to your pelleted nuclei and resuspend it. Transfer tube to a room-temperature rack.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":29,"length":7}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"anhec","text":"At room-temperature add 13.34 μL of methanol-free formaldehyde (16% stock solution) for a final concentration of 0.2% formaldehyde in your nuclei. Close the tube and nutate for 5 minutes at room-temperature.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"933qr","text":"To quench fixation, per reaction add 56.1 μL of fresh 2.5M Glycine (0.94g per 5mL stock), 50 μL of 1M Tris pH 8.0, and 13.3 μL of 7.5% BSA. Mix using a pipette.  Incubate on ice for 10 minutes.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3q70q","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
{"blocks":[{"key":"8uu5l","text":"Spin at 750xg for 5 min at 4ºC.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"6n5rn","text":"(Optional) Count your nuclei (step 2.16) again here if you want an accurate count of how many you have and to check if your nuclei are in good condition. It is also acceptable to use the counts (from step 3.7) as rough estimates for your downstream experiments.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"f2t4s","text":"Remove supernatant and add 500 μL of cold HDT-2RI to resuspend the nuclei pellet. If the goal is to aliquot nuclei into more tubes for multiple experiments, split your sample into different BSA coated tubes during this step. Label tubes as desired.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":42,"length":7}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
{"blocks":[{"key":"4bpmq","text":"Spin at 750xg for 5 min at 4ºC. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"2a20n","text":"Remove supernatant and freeze dry pellets at -80 degrees C. Note: We have found success at just placing the dry nuclei pellet into a freezer without flash freezing.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":60,"length":104}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

title: Nuclear Isolation and Purification Protocol for Single-Cell Methods
title_html: Nuclear Isolation and Purification Protocol for Single-Cell Methods

versions.title: Nuclear Isolation and Purification Protocol for Single-Cell Methods
versions.title_html: Nuclear Isolation and Purification Protocol for Single-Cell Methods

creator.name: Guillermo Barreto Corona
creator.affiliation: Broad Institute of MIT and Harvard

warning: {"blocks":[{"key":"88h0u","text":"This protocol may be used on primate tissue (human and non-human) however it should be noted that even with proper screening of samples, this protocol produces aerosols that could be potentially damaging to your health. It is recommended to use effective personal protective equipment (PPE) and the nuclear isolation part of this protocol be done in a biosafety cabinet (BSC) to protect yourself, the sample, and the public.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
